Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Enabling a new technology for reconfigurable RF front-ends and antenna array systems through phase-change materials.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract (Proposal #1310400 and #1310257):

Intellectual Merit: The objective of this research is to develop new radio-frequency front-end systems, filters, transmission lines, and antenna array topologies with multi-reconfigurable characteristics through the unique properties of phase-change materials. The defined research tasks span from fundamental materials science to system integration, creating an intersection that leads to a new path in the design of reconfigurable radio-frequency front-ends and antenna arrays. The components that will be developed are expected to have a wide range of responses. These responses will be enabled by the following approaches: (1) the changes in the electric properties of vanadium dioxide across its phase transition, (2) the compatibility with other components of different characteristic impedance due to the controlled impedance matching and bandwidth through the variable resistivity and dielectric permittivity, and (3) multiple frequencies with "analog" tuning as well as patterns and polarizations. Vanadium dioxide is a multifunctional phase change material (i.e. a smart material) that will be integrated in specific radio-frequency designs in the form of patterned thin films. The drastic and abrupt continuous variability in the dielectric permittivity and resistivity of patterned vanadium dioxide films across their phase change will be used as the reconfiguring element, while their hysteretic behavior will be used to program multiple states in the devices. The reconfigurability and programmability of the proposed devices will be characterized in terms of amplitude and phase response.

Broader Impact: The integration of multifunctional phase change materials in antenna and microwave component designs adds a new degree of freedom for radio-frequency component engineers. The proposed research will produce multi-reconfigurable antenna arrays and will benefit applications including array miniaturization, feed networks, and composite transmission lines. The educational and outreach plan spans from elementary school through the doctorate level and involves scientific presentations at conferences, journal publications, social media, course enrichment, an open-source software development, and the promotion of a multidisciplinary learning experience through the exchange of complementary knowledge between the two institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project is to explore new ways to develop antennas that have multiple funcitonalities.

Typically an antenna serves a single purpose. An antenna however can be made reconfigurable and serve multiple purposes. For example, single reconfigurable antenna could operate at 1.9 GHz (standard 4G cellphone band) but could also operate at 6 GHz for when the phone enters a 5G-enabled zone. Traditional techniques to achieve antenna reconfigurability rely on off-the-shelf components (pin diodes, varactors, transistors, MEMS). Each category has several advantages but also some disadvantages, for example MEMS are linear but difficult to implement, while diodes and varactors are space-qualified technologies but non-linear and thus introduce dispersion on the signal. 

In this research our team explored for the very first time how we can reconfigure an antenna by using a functional material (vanadium dioxide or VO2). The VO2 is a material that has an insulator-to-semiconductor transition. In other words, under certain stimulus (e.g. above 68 degrees Celsius), VO2 switches from an approximately open circuit state (insulator) to an approximately short-circuit state (conductor). Using this property we explored what, if any, electromagnetic devices could be made reconfigurable. 

Our research focused on coplanar folded slot type of antennas, where we have extensive expertise. Prototypes were developed that demonstrated antennas that have frequency tunability more than 40% using integrated VO2 thin-films as RF switches. This a huge advancement considering that the current state of the art in frequency reconfigurability is typically limited to less than 25%.

This research helped us learn a lot on how to integrate vanadium dioxide with electromagnetic devices. This is not a trivial process and involves knowledge of materials as well as electromagnetics, which are rarely found together. 

We demonstrated that with the integration of multifunctional phase change materials in antenna and microwave component designs we can add a new degree of freedom to the toolset of the antenna designer. The antennas of the figure have multiple frequencies and polarizations, and can be used as elements in antenna arrays that will have on-demand element factors – thus they enable a new dimension in remote sensing, medical and radar applications through multiple spectra and polarizations sensing using a single device. Other applications that benefit include antenna array miniaturization, arrays with reduced beam squinting, antenna feed networks, high directive couplers, and composite transmission lines that provide zero phase at multiple frequencies.

The skills and knowledge obtained from this research have helped enrich four courses:  Advanced Electromagnetics (Anagnostou), Antenna Applications (Anagnostou), Electronic Devices (Sepúlveda) and Principles of Electronic Devices (Sepúlveda), while all involved students are now enjoying successful careers in the areas of antennas or advanced materials. The promotion of a multidisciplinary learning experience took place through the exchange of complementary knowledge between the two institution viaexchange visits from both PIs and their students. Several undergraduate research (REU) students were also supported or co-supported by this project and they were trained on materials and antenna measurements. Some of these students measured the properties of vanadium dioxide thin films, while others implemented wirelessly controlled reconfigurable arrays. All the undergraduate students were very motivated and produced high quality results. All the students enjoy now very successful careers in relevant industries or have enrolled in relevant PhD programs at some of the best universities in the US. 

This research has also resulted in a collaboration between MSU and the new institution of PI Anagnostou (Heriot Watt University), while it has attracted the interest of other agencies and small defence-focused businesses in Europe and Canada, creating new multi-national collaborations. It also attracted the interest of researchers from other universities such as KAUST, who are developing vanadium dioxide nanoinks and shared prototypes with us.

It is also worth noting that this research has attracted the interest of faculty from Optics (Laser), and has inspired many students who found it exciting and wish to conduct some portion of their research on antennas. 

Last but not least, this research supported also junior faculty early in their careers, and students from the geographically underrepresented upper mid-western area of the United States.
